We know that an (n,n) -matrix \Mtrx{A}
represents uniquely a linear transformation
We assume standard coordinates of \RNr[n] here. – Lookup this fact.
T\from \RNr[n]\to \RNr[n] via T(\Vect{x}) := \Mtrx{A}\Vect{x} . So the question arises: is there a way of extracting from \Mtrx{A} how it transforms \RNr[n] in terms of the
main types of linear transformations
Look up the main types of linear transformations
we studied earlier: scalings, rotations, shear transformations?

Eigentheory tells us to search for lines in \RNr[n] which \Mtrx{A}
transforms into themselves
Explanation / Illustration of terminology
‘Eigen’ is a German word for ‘self’. It is used here to refer to the property of \Mtrx{A} of transforming a line into itself.
. The only way \Mtrx{A} can transform a line L into itself is by scaling it by a constant factor, call it \lambda . This means that, for every vector \Vect{x} in L , \Mtrx{A}\Vect{x} = \lambda \Vect{x} . If \Vect{x}\neq \Vect{0} , we call \Vect{x} an eigenvector of \Mtrx{A} , and \lambda its eigenvalue. We now distinguish three situations:

\RNr[n] has a basis \EuScript{B}
consisting of eigenvectors
An illustration of this situation
of \Mtrx{A} . – It follows that \RNr[n] splits into subspaces V_1 , ... , V_k which get scaled by eigenvalues \lambda_1 , ... , \lambda_k of \Mtrx{A} , respectively. Now if we represent the given linear map by a matrix \Mtrx{B} with respect to the basis \EuScript{B} , then \Mtrx{B} is a diagonal matrix. Accordingly, \Mtrx{A} is called diagonalizable.

\Mtrx{A} involves shearing transformations. – In this case the search for eigenvalues proceeds as in case 1. However, the search for eigenvectors needs to be extended so as to include so called generalized eigenvectors.
Thus the main question that remains is: how do we find subspaces of \RNr[n] on which \Mtrx{A} acts in one of the way described above? – To answer this question we use the determinant operation:
Given an eigenvector \lambda of \Mtrx{A} , we find (generalized) eigenvectors of \Mtrx{A} as the nonzero vectors in the null space of (\Mtrx{A} - \lambda\cdot \Mtrx{A})^r .

The deeper issues of eigentheory will only be stated and explained as far as possible with the elementary tools available to us now. Some proofs will be omitted as an elegant treatment of eigentheory is most easily developed within the more advanced theory of rings and modules.
